I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

 
1. 
I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to the Gulf JP NS Company Limited (JPNS) for the Nong Saeng Natural Gas Power Project up 
to $170,000,000 to  be financed from the ordinary  capital  resources  of  the  Asian  Development 
Bank  (ADB)  without  government  guarantee.  If  approved,  the  project  will  constitute  ADB’s  fifth 
private sector investment in Thailand. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 

II. 

THE PROJECT 

 
A. 

Project Identification and Description 

1. 

Project Identification 

2. 
The Thai power sector is structured under a single-buyer model whereby the Electricity 
Generating Authority of Thailand (EGAT), the state utility, enables private sector participation in 
the  power  generation  sector  while  maintaining  control  over  system  planning,  operation,  and 
pricing. EGAT owns and operates the largest share of Thailand’s installed generation capacity 
and  is  the  country’s  single  wholesale  purchaser  of  electricity  and  supplier  (as  transmission 
owner  and  operator)  to  the  country’s  two  state-owned  electricity  distribution  authorities:  the 
Metropolitan Electricity Authority and the Provincial Electricity Authority. 
 
3. 
The  government  has  opened  access  to  private  sector  participation  in  the  generation 
business  through  three  public  –  private  partnership  (PPP)  programs:  independent  power 
producers (IPPs), small power producers, and very small power producers. The IPP and small 
power  producer  programs  allow  private  developers  to  construct,  own,  and  operate  power 
projects and enter into power purchase agreements (PPAs) with EGAT with terms of up to 25 
years.  The  very  small  power  producer  program  allows  power  producers  with  projects  of  10 
megawatts (MW) or less to sell power to the Metropolitan Electricity Authority and the Provincial 
Electricity  Authority.  IPPs  are  large  private  power  producers  with  generating  capacity  greater 
than  90  MW  that  use  commercial  coal,  natural  gas,  and  heavy  oil  and  sell  their  electricity  to 
EGAT  through  PPAs.  Thailand’s  IPP  program  was  introduced  in  the  early  1990s  to  promote 
competition,  enhance  generating  efficiency,  lower  electricity  prices,  and  reduce  the  financial 
burden on the Government of Thailand of expanding generation to meet rising demand. Since 
the  inception  of  the  IPP  program,  its  share  of  electricity  generation  supplying  Thailand  has 
steadily increased 
 
In accordance with the government’s policy to promote private sector participation in the 
4. 
power sector, EGAT invited qualified generators in 2007 to participate in IPP bidding. This was 
the  second  IPP  bidding  round  since the  program  was  initiated and  the first  IPP  bidding  round 
since  the  Asian  financial  crisis. 1  At  the  time,  ADB  was  asked  for  financial  assistance  and 
expressed to potential bidders interest in providing a guarantee that would help extend the tenor 
of IPP financial assistance.  
 
5. 
In 2008, the financial crisis triggered by subprime mortgage lending in the United States 
spiraled into a global economic crisis. Thailand reduced its economic growth forecasts as power 
demand declined significantly. Accordingly, the recently awarded IPP projects were postponed,

Despite  these factors,  the  Thai  economy demonstrated  remarkable  signs  of  recovery  in  2010,

of 2009. The latest demand forecast indicates that Thailand must promptly bring new capacity 
online to avoid an impending supply as the reserve margin is expected to reach a critical level 
by 2019.2

B. 

Development Impact, Outcome, and Outputs 

1. 

Impact 

9. 
The project supports long-term, sustainable, and inclusive economic growth through the 
provision  of  reliable,  low-cost,  and  efficient  base-load  power.  A  major  challenge  for  ADB 
developing  member  countries  such  as  Thailand  is  bringing  significant  new  power  generation 
online to maintain economic growth. Underinvestment in the power sector reduces the integrity 
of  the  system,  making  it  more  prone  to  outages.  Supply  disruptions  are  costly  for  local 
businesses and discourage foreign direct investment. The project’s timely addition of 1,600 MW 
of capacity will help Thailand maintain a reserve margin above the Ministry of Energy’s critical 
threshold  of  15%.  Low  cost  is  important  for  making  electricity  accessible  and  affordable  to 
reduce  poverty.  Low-cost  electricity  enhances  Thailand’s  labor  productivity  and  global 
competiveness  and  expands  livelihood  opportunities.  Further,  energy projects  that  use natural 
gas  and  efficient  combined-cycle  technology  are  more  sustainable  than  coal-fired  projects, 
which is the only other IPP alternative for adding new domestic base-load capacity in Thailand. 
 

2. 

Outcome 

10. 
The outcome of the project is the provision of competitively-priced power generated from 
technically  and  financially  stable  gas-fired  technology,  which  emits  substantially  less  carbon 
dioxide than a coal-fired generation. Using natural gas with efficient combined-cycle technology6 
contributes  to  long-term  sustainable  growth.  In addition, the  project  will  provide environmental 
and social benefits. Compared with coal-fired generation, the only IPP alternative for domestic 
base-load  generation,  the  project  will  avoid  5.7  million  tons  of  carbon  dioxide  emissions  per 
annum,  as  well  as  dust  and  ash  waste.  Cleaner  air  and  a  lower  carbon  footprint  provide 
healthier  and  more  sustainable  living  conditions  for  the  poor.  Other  socioeconomic  benefits 
include employment creation and tax contributions.

3 

 

  
4 

 

The project reduces poverty by providing a significant amount of electricity at a low cost, 
11. 
which is essential for economic growth and human development.7 On average, the project will 
contribute  11,845  gigawatt-hours  of  cleaner  energy  to  the  grid  per  annum  by  2015.  Modern 
forms of energy must be available, accessible, and affordable to communities, businesses, and 
households  to  reduce  poverty  and  set  development  on  an  inclusive  path.  Energy  can  be 
considered the  missing  Millennium  Development Goal  because  it  is  a  significant  driver  toward 
achieving the others.  
 

3. 

Outputs 

12. 
The  project  outputs  include  the  first  PPP  worth  over  $1  billion  to  reach  financial  close 
and  the first  IPP  of over 1,000  MW  to be  brought  online  in  Thailand  since  the global financial 
crisis.  Both  are  important  signals  to  the  market  and  power  sector  that  will  demonstrate 
confidence  in  the  country  as  it  recovers  from  the  economic  downturn  and  recent  political 
disruptions.  The  financial  close  will  be  made  possible  through  ADB  and  a  bilateral  co-lender, 
which will catalyze the long-term financing required for infrastructure development. The design 
and  monitoring  framework  in  Appendix  1  outlines  the  project’s  impact,  outcome,  and  output 
indicators. 
 
C. 

Alignment with ADB Strategy and Operations  

1. 

Consistency with Strategy 2020 

13. 
Capitalizing  on  ADB’s  core  strength  of  financing  infrastructure  development,  Strategy 
20208 sets  forth  that  ADB  will  help  expand  the  supply  of  energy;  promote  energy  efficiency; 
support clean energy; and facilitate the removal of policy, institutional, regulatory, technological, 
and legal constraints on efficient energy use. Strategy 2020 aims to promote a larger role for the 
private sector in financing infrastructure development by supporting PPP. 
 

Consistency with the Country Strategy 

2. 
The central thrust of ADB’s country partnership strategy for Thailand, 2007–20119 is to 
14. 
address  the  main  constraints  on  its  achieving  sustainable  economic  growth.  Ensuring  the 
development  of  infrastructure,  which  is  one  of  three  core  strategic  areas  of  the  country 
partnership  strategy,  will  ultimately  shape  the  magnitude,  direction,  and  sustainability  of 
Thailand’s future economic growth and development.  
 

3. 
Consistency with the Sector Strategy and Relevant ADB Operations   
ADB’s  Energy  Policy10 emphasizes  investments  in  energy  efficiency,  least-cost  supply, 
15. 
private  sector  participation,  and  wider  access  for  the  poor.  ADB  supports  projects  that  use 
efficient technologies such as combined cycle, as well as projects that incorporate state-of-the-
art  emission-control  equipment.  Natural  gas  is  preferred  over  coal  for  providing  base-load 
electricity.

and equity return.

 4. 

Lessons Learned from Previous Operations 

16. 
In 2003, ADB approved financing for the BLCP Power Project (footnote 1), a successful 
conventional  power  plant  in  Thailand  under  the  IPP  program.  In  2009,  an  extended  annual 
review  was  conducted  and  found  that  the  project  had  played  an  important  role  in  securing 
reliable, least-cost power in Thailand, as one of the lowest-cost, highest-dispatch generators in 
the  sector,  after  hydropower  imports  from  the  Lao  People’s  Democratic  Republic.  The  project 
serves today as a model in Thailand for developing and implementing IPP projects sensitive to 
environment, safety, and community relation standards.

IV. 

POLICY COMPLIANCE 

A. 

Environment and Social Safeguards 

18. 
The  project  is  classified  category  A  for  environment,  and  C  for  both  involuntary 
resettlement  and  indigenous  people.   An  environmental  impact  assessment  was  prepared, 
which  has  identified  the  potential  environmental  and  social  impacts  and  risks  of  the  project, 
including an assessment of cumulative air quality impacts covering all major projects in the air 
shed.  The  environmental  impact  assessment  was  posted  on  ADB  website  in  January 
2011.  Adequate mitigation measures are incorporated in the environmental management plan 
of  the  environmental  impact  assessment,  which  JPNS  is  committed  to  fully  implement,  with 
submission of semiannual progress reports to meet ADB's compliance. Extensive consultations 
with affected people have been conducted in accordance with ADB requirements.12 
 
B. 

Anticorruption Policy  

19. 
The  borrower  was advised of  ADB’s  Anticorruption  Policy  (1998,  as  amended  to date) 
and  its  Policy  on  Combating  Money  Laundering  and  the  Financing  of  Terrorism  (2003). 
Consistent with its commitment to good governance, accountability, and transparency, ADB will 
require JPNS to institute, maintain, and comply with internal procedures and controls following 
international  best  practice  standards  for  the  purpose  of  preventing  corruption  or  money 
laundering  activities  or  the  financing  of  terrorism  and  covenant  with  ADB  to  refrain  from 
engaging in such activities. The loan documentation between ADB and JPNS will further allow 
ADB  to  investigate  any  violation  or  potential  violation  of  these  undertakings  and  will  include 
appropriate anticorruption provisions and remedies for ADB in the event of noncompliance.
